bullets.text: ML is a subfield of AI focused on systems learning from data without explicit programming.
Core idea: systems learn patterns and make decisions with minimal human intervention.
Used in image recognition, NLP, predictive analytics, and autonomous vehicles.
Growth driven by large datasets, improved computational power, and advanced algorithms.
Supervised Learning: Trained on labeled data to predict known outputs (e.g., regression, classification).
Unsupervised Learning: Trained on unlabeled data to find hidden patterns (e.g., clustering, dimensionality reduction).
Reinforcement Learning: Agent learns by interacting with an environment to maximize rewards (e.g., robotics, gaming).
Model Training: Adjusting internal parameters to minimize prediction differences (loss function).
Features and Labels: Input variables (features) and target outputs (labels) in supervised learning.
Training and Testing Sets: Data split to train the model and evaluate its performance on unseen data.
Overfitting: Model learns training data too well, including noise, performing poorly on new data.
Underfitting: Model is too simple, failing to capture important data patterns.
Linear Regression: Models linear relationship for continuous output prediction.
Logistic Regression: Used for classification, predicting probability of class membership.
Decision Trees: Non-linear model splitting data based on feature values, easy to interpret.
Random Forest: Ensemble method combining multiple decision trees for improved performance.
Support Vector Machines (SVM): Finds optimal hyperplane for classification, effective in high dimensions.
Neural Networks: Inspired by the human brain, learns complex patterns for deep learning applications.
Healthcare: Disease diagnosis, drug discovery, personalized treatment.
Finance: Fraud detection, credit scoring, algorithmic trading.
Marketing: Customer segmentation, personalized recommendations, targeted advertising.
Autonomous Vehicles: Processing sensor data, decision-making, navigation.
Natural Language Processing (NLP): Language translation, sentiment analysis, text summarization.
Training and Testing: Evaluate performance using separate datasets with metrics like accuracy, MSE.
Cross-Validation: Ensures model generalizes well by splitting data into multiple subsets for training/testing.
Hyperparameter Tuning: Optimizing model settings (hyperparameters) using techniques like grid search.
Data Quality and Quantity: Requires large amounts of accurate, consistent, and complete data.
Interpretability: Complex models (e.g., deep learning) are difficult to understand.
Bias in Data: Models can inherit biases from training data, leading to unfair outcomes.
Overfitting and Underfitting: Common issues affecting model generalization.
Continuous evolution with advancements in deep learning, reinforcement learning, and explainable AI (XAI).
Increased integration into daily life across healthcare, education, entertainment, and transportation.
Growing importance of ethical considerations and responsible AI practices.
